The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.
Free Text

I am trying to catch someone,' said Frankenstein. 'That is why I have come so far north on the ice.'

Mary Shelley
 
 

Survey
University of Auckland
Objectives describe the expected outcomes of the learning and should define what the learners will be able to do when they have completed the learning tasks.
Type the learning objectives for this resource.

You will interpret an excerpt from Mary Shelley's "Frankenstein" through the obtention of new vocabulary and the identification of literary elements in the text to improve your reading comprehension skills. 

This activity is aimed at a B1 English level.
Before you read...

Prerequisite knowledge refers to the knowledge learners should already have in order to be able to effectively complete the learning. Examples of pre-knowledge can be:
  • Learners must have level 4 English
  • Learners must be able to assemble standard power tools
Describe the prerequisite knowledge learners should have to effectively complete this learning.

Before you start reading, consider checking the current vocabulary you possess to identify if this lesson will be too difficult for you or not.

The next exercise contains essential terms that are needed to understand the other activities.
University of Auckland

An activity can be defined as a task or set of tasks a learner must complete. Provide a clear statement of the task and consider any conditions that may help or hinder the learner in the performance of the task.
Describe the tasks the learners should complete.

Instructions: Click on the corresponding letters to discover the 10 words in this hangman activity. Use the definition and spaces provided to guide you.

Keep in mind there is a time limit, and only 5 opportunities!
Victor Frankenstein's Story
More than words
University of Auckland

An activity can be defined as a task or set of tasks a learner must complete. Provide a clear statement of the task and consider any conditions that may help or hinder the learner in the performance of the task.
Describe the tasks the learners should complete.

To obtain a higher comprehension of literary or academic readings, it is important to possess an extensive knowledge of vocabulary.

Before reading, search the definition of the terms below to encourage a higher comprehension of Frankenstein's Chapter 1.    

  • captain 
  • mast
  • huge
  • through
  • sledge
  • round
  • sailor
  • enough
  • faint (fainted)
  • to be pleased
  • disappear (disappeared)
You may use a physical dictionary or click on "Cambridge Dictionary"  to search for the meanings online.
Frankenstein by Mary Shelley
University of Auckland

The Reading Activity will primarily be used to check a learner's comprehension of a given text. This can be done by asking the learner to reflect on the reading and respond to questions about the reading, or by having them complete some other possibly more physical task based on the reading.

Teachers should keep the following in mind when using this iDevice:

  1. Think about the number of different types of activity planned for your resource that will be visually signalled in the content. Avoid using too many different types or classification of activities otherwise learner may become confused. Usually three or four different types are more than adequate for a teaching resource.
  2. From a visual design perspective, avoid having two iDevices immediately following each other without any text in between. If this is required, rather collapse two questions or events into one iDevice.
  3. Think about activities where the perceived benefit of doing the activity outweighs the time and effort it will take to complete the activity.
Enter the details of the reading including reference details. The referencing style used will depend on the preference of your faculty or department.
What to read
Now that you know some of the words that you will find in the text, read Chapter 1.
Describe the tasks related to the reading learners should undertake. This helps demonstrate relevance for learners.
If you come across any new terms, look them up in a dictionary too!
Use feedback to provide a summary of the points covered in the reading, or as a starting point for further analysis of the reading by posing a question or providing a statement to begin a debate.
First catch
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
University of Auckland

Reflection is a teaching method often used to connect theory to practice. Reflection tasks often provide learners with an opportunity to observe and reflect on their observations before presenting these as a piece of academic work. Journals, diaries, profiles and portfolios are useful tools for collecting observation data. Rubrics and guides can be effective feedback tools.
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Reflective question:

In maximum 10 sentences, summarize what you read in Chapter 1.

When you finish your writing, click on the button below.
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
Button

Hi, 

In your summary did you include the characters? did you mention the setting? the plot? the point of view in which it is written? the tone of the story? the theme? or what about the conflict?

Continue on the next page to connect these terms to Reading Comprehension.

In your summary did you include the characters? did you mention the setting? the plot? the point of view in which it is written? the tone of the story? the theme? or what about the conflict?

Continue on the next page to connect these terms to Reading Comprehension.

Having the ability to clearly identify who the characters in a text are improves the range of comprehension that a reader has on a piece of text. 

When you read Chapter 1, did you identify all of the characters? Complete the next activity to check. 

Instructions: Based on the definitions provided, search for the 5 characters from Chapter 1 in the word search. There is a time limit, work fast!
University of Auckland

An activity can be defined as a task or set of tasks a learner must complete. Provide a clear statement of the task and consider any conditions that may help or hinder the learner in the performance of the task.
Describe the tasks the learners should complete.

Imagining the setting also increases comprehension, not to mention that it is a great part of the magic in reading.

During Chapter 1, what places did you imagine?  

Instructions: The column on the left includes pieces of text from Chapter 1 and the column on the right different images. Match the pieces of text with the image that best represents the author's descriptions.

To navigate through the different texts and images, click on the blue arrows. To check if your match is correct, click on the button with a question mark.

Reflection is a teaching method often used to connect theory to practice. Reflection tasks often provide learners with an opportunity to observe and reflect on their observations before presenting these as a piece of academic work. Journals, diaries, profiles and portfolios are useful tools for collecting observation data. Rubrics and guides can be effective feedback tools.
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Reflective question:

Keeping in mind the literary elements of a text helps focus on the details of a reading, this way expanding comprehension of what the author wished to share through his/her writing.

Compare your first summary with this second assignment. After taking into account the literary elements, did it help you understand more what Frankenstein's Chapter 1 was about? In the reflection part of your notebook briefly explain why yes, or why not.
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
Activity validation
Validate your activity

Duration:
10:00

To finish this activity you will answer a validation quiz. It is important to consider these things:

      1. To get this activity validated, you must score at least 80% in this quiz.

      2. In order not to lose points, it is important to check not only your answer but your spelling too.

Click here:                validation quiz
